indicators.justification:
Although Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations or a member of UNFCCC, it still complies with the UNFCCC international conventions, self-checking and disclosing relevant information.[1] Data is available from the national government open data platform[2] as well as the EPA.[3]

[1] IEA.org. Chinese Taipei. https://www.iea.org/countries/chinese-taipei
[2] Government open data platform. data.gov.tw
[3] EPA data. https://www.epa.gov.tw/eng/2C04F91E41A2000B

Data contains detailed information on sources of greenhouse gas emissions.
Emissions data includes, or site where emissions data is made available links to, details of land use effects on emissions.
The dataset contains unique identifiers for greenhouse gas emissions that allow easy assessment across inventories, reduction commitments, and sources.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.

indicators.justification:
"the long-expected draft clause in the Company Act on de facto beneficial owner disclosure, due to the work of lobbyists, has been a crippled version since 2018. Only a company's direct and major shareholders are required to be disclosed to the concerned authorities — on a government platform that is not made public."[1]

[1] Financial Secrecy Index https://fsi.taxjustice.net/PDF/Taiwan.pdf

indicators.justification:
Land use data, at least in Taipei, is quite complete.[1] Land use data is available also by county [2] but every county has different information, and some information is not open to public (requires registration/payment). Different counties provide different information. The land data ecosystem in Taiwan is quite fragmented.

[1]New Taipei City Land Bureau. 2018. Study on on cadastral open data and value added application. https://www.rde.ntpc.gov.tw/userfiles/1160700/files/05%E5%9C%B0%E7%B1%8D%E8%B3%87%E6%96%99%E9%96%8B%E6%94%BE%E8%88%87%E5%8A%A0%E5%80%BC%E6%87%89%E7%94%A8%E4%B9%8B%E7%A0%94%E7%A9%B6-%E4%BB%A5%E6%96%B0%E5%8C%97%E5%B8%82%E9%83%BD%E6%9B%B4%E4%B8%89%E7%AE%AD%E7%82%BA%E4%BE%8B.pdf

[2] Ministry of the Interior Real Estate Information Platform. https://pip.moi.gov.tw/V3/Z/SCRZ0206.aspx

indicators.justification:
On the whole, Taiwan's budget and expenditures for governance are transparent[1]

[1] Fiscal transparency of APEC countries: A Comparison. https://ws.ndc.gov.tw/001/administrator/10/relfile/5644/2682/0062745.pdf

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

indicators.justification:
Civil servants above a certain level (middle and high-level) must declare relevant information, and it is also applicable to the whole country.
Although there are occasional cases of malpractice, for example, some poor public servants will use fake heads or cash to evade, but most of the normal circumstances can eliminate public office malpractice.[1] Read more about it in this article [2].

[1] Act on Property Declaration by Public Servants. https://law.moj.gov.tw/ENG/LawClass/LawAll.aspx?pcode=I0070005
[2]The Political Economy on Property Declaration by Public Servants https://www.airitilibrary.com/Publication/alDetailedMesh1?DocID=U0001-0408201013395000

indicators.justification:
Taiwan's government procurement system is transparent and open, and it will even announce whether the same company has received too many government procurement cases for public reference.[1]

[1] Xu Zhiyi, Wang Zhuxun, Liu Yulin, Xu Huaiyuan. 108 Mingguo/2019. Government Data Opening and Data Management. https://pa.nccu.edu.tw/upload/2/publication_file/32/56-4%20%E8%A8%B1%E5%BF%97%E7%BE%A9%E7%AD%89--%E6%94%BF%E5%BA%9C%E8%B3%87%E6%96%99%E9%96%8B%E6%94%BE%E8%88%87%E8%B3%87%E6%96%99%E7%AE%A1%E7%90%86.pdf

indicators.justification:
The open data environment is nationally led but implementation is done at a ministerial or local level. However, the hackathon [1] and collaborations with civic tech [2] have been national (albeit ad hoc) [3]. The Advanced Action Plan for Open Government Data provides the policy thrust for this support [4].

The government is very supportive of data reuse. A high profile example includes Join Taiwan and vTaiwan, which are both civic participation platforms overseen by Audrey Tang, Taiwan's Digital Minister [2]

Recently, during the COVID pandemic, the Taiwan government was praised for working with data from the general public as well as government data to create an app platform for those searching for mask availability [5].

[1] Presidential Hackathon. https://presidential-hackathon.taiwan.gov.tw/en/
[2] Article about vTaiwan and Join. https://www.technologyreview.com/2018/08/21/240284/the-simple-but-ingenious-system-taiwan-uses-to-crowdsource-its-laws/
[3] Open Culture Foundation. Taiwan Open Government Report 2014-2016. https://opengovreport.ocf.tw/en/report/#tab-3
[4] National Development Council. The Advanced Action Plan for Open Government Data https://data.gov.tw/en/the-advance-act-plan-for-open-government-data
[5] About the Mask Map Platform. https://fightcovid.edu.tw/specific-topics/mask-map

responses.response_text: There is widespread and regular evidence of government supporting and encouraging data reuse, framed by a long-term strategy.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of a government strategy to support and encourage data reuse?
There is evidence of government efforts to support open government data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support big data reuse in a general sense.

There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by scholars and academic institutions.

Government support for data reuse involves data challenges.

Government support for data reuse involves communication and community building efforts.
Government support for data reuse involves running information sessions on how to use particular datasets, or how to reuse government data in general.
Government support for data reuse involves the release of funding schemes

responses.response_text: Support assessed is at national level.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the support assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
In 2013, the Taiwan government started the open data initiatives[1]. There are no laws on open data, but in fact, because the bulk of the framework on open data in Taiwan is made up of executive orders, the entire open data environment is dependent on the backing of senior political leaders[2].

[1] Jonathan Stray. 2013. How does a country get to open data? https://www.niemanlab.org/2013/04/how-does-a-country-get-to-open-data-what-taiwan-can-teach-us-about-the-evolution-of-access/
[2] Open Culture Foundation. Taiwan Open Government Report 2014-2016. https://opengovreport.ocf.tw/en/#tab-0

responses.response_text: There is evidence of an active government-led open government data initiative.
responses.subquestion_text: Has there been any form of government-led open government data initiative during the study period?
There is a government team in place supporting open data activities.
There is an allocated budget for open data activities.
There is a well-maintained open data portal.
There is guidance and support for government publication of open data.
Senior political leaders back the open data initiative.

responses.response_text: The open data initiatives covers much of both national and sub-national government.
responses.subquestion_text: How widely does this, or similar, open data initiatives apply?

indicators.justification:
Local governments either have their own platforms or share on the national platform[1]. But there is evidence that some local governments are able to open much less data than others, showing evidence of a rural/urban divide[2]. 6 special municipalities have adopted the Open Data Charter[3].

[1] Taipei Data Catalog. https://data.taipei/#/dataset/topic
[2] Open Culture Foundation. Taiwan Open Government Report 2014-2016. https://opengovreport.ocf.tw/en/#tab-0
[3] Taiwan Today. 2018. Taiwan's 6 special municipalities adopt Open Data Charter. https://taiwantoday.tw/news.php?unit=2,6,10,15,18&post=138968

https://hdl.handle.net/11296/574dg2
http://joemls.dils.tku.edu.tw/fulltext/56/56-1/Tung-Mou%20Yang.pdf

responses.subquestion_text: To what extent do city, regional, and local governments have the capability to effectively manage data?
There is evidence of local governments having open data initiatives.
There is evidence of local governments having current open data policies in place.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place to provide a comprehensive framework for data sharing.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place for consistent data management and publication.
There is evidence of local governments providing training to civil servants on data literacy and skills.
There is evidence of local governments providing support for data reuse.

responses.response_text: The examples given are exceptions: the majority of cities and regions do not have the capacity to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: How widespread are local capacities to effectively manage data?

indicators.justification:
There is no evidence of data-related trainings in Taiwan [1]. However, there is evidence of the desire to train civil servants[2],[3].

Training delivered covers data analysis, visualisations and storytelling techniques.
Training delivered covers specific technical topics for data centred roles.
Training on data addresses non-technical public servants.
Training on data is focused on specific positions already working with data.

indicators.justification:
The 'Act on Property-Declaration by Public Servants' [1] require declaring of property every year, but the information is disclosed in written form in the bulletin, which is not an open data format. The information is provided once a year and it is difficult to compare. Various data on political integrity are still incomparable.[2]

[1] Act on Property Declaration of Public Servants. https://law.moj.gov.tw/ENG/LawClass/LawAll.aspx?pcode=I0070005

[2] AIT. 2019. Human Rights Report on Taiwan. https://www.ait.org.tw/2019-human-rights-report-taiwan-part/

responses.response_text: The datasets use a limited number of common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.
The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

responses.response_text: There is no consistency of identifiers or identification systems.
responses.subquestion_text: To what degree do the datasets associated with this theme use consistent identifiers and identification systems for elements that appear in more than one dataset?

indicators.justification:
There are no laws requiring the publication of beneficial ownership information. However, there is a law that governs the collection of company  information [1] but it does not require the publication of it. Some limited company information is published via the Department of Commerce [2] but it only includes Name of Company/Business, Unified Business No. or Factory Registration No.; Address; Name of Company Representative; Name of Director/Supervisor/Managerial Officer; and Cross Domain Information

[1] Ministry of Economic Affairs. 2018. Company Act. https://law.moj.gov.tw/ENG/LawClass/LawAll.aspx?pcode=J0080001
[2] Department of Commerce, MOEA. Get information about companies or businesses in Taiwan. https://findbiz.nat.gov.tw/fts/query/QueryBar/queryInit.do?request_locale=en&fhl=en

Definitions comprehensively cover ownership.

There are guidelines (Based on the W3C WAI framework) for the accessibility of websites, which is relevant insofar as data is being made available online[1]. Additionally, there is an awarding program for data quality.[2]

Framework is limited to metadata and API standards.

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
There are minimum standards for metadata when government data is catalogued or published.
There is a standardised process for publishing and updating published government data.
There are technical standards, including common data models, codelists, and identifiers for management and publication of government data.

There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

responses.response_text: The data management approaches assessed generally apply across the whole public sector.

indicators.justification:
Taiwans has been prioritizing smart/e-government development. Smart government was launched in 2017 as part of the Digital Nation and Innovative Economic Development Program (2017-2025). The government rolled out a second iteration of the program (2021-2025), and it is governed by this policy: Digital Government Program 2.0 of Taiwan (2021-2025) [1]. It discusses the utility of data sharing for the program.

However, it is not a legal document nor is it a policy, only a plan, and there is no comprehensive framework specifically for data sharing.

[1] National Development Council. 2020. Digital Government Program 2.0 of Taiwan 2021-2025. https://ws.ndc.gov.tw/Download.ashx?u=LzAwMS9hZG1pbmlzdHJhdG9yLzExL3JlbGZpbGUvMC8yMDYwLzVkYTI0OWMzLTVkYzYtNGI0Mi1iMTdiLWEyMWNkNmM0NWM0Zi5wZGY%3d&n=RGlnaXRhbCBHb3Zlcm5tZW50IFByb2dyYW0gMl8wIG9mIFRhaXdhbiAoMjAyMS0yMDI1KS5wZGY%3d&icon=..pdf

responses.response_text: A framework exists but lacks full force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework covers data sharing within government.
The framework covers how government should share data with other sectors.
The framework covers data sharing from other sectors to government.
The framework covers data sharing within the private sector.
The framework explicitly focuses on artificial intelligence uses of data.

responses.response_text: The framework assessed covers all government agencies, and many themes.
responses.subquestion_text: How broad is the coverage of legal or policy frameworks for data sharing for the public good?
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
The Taiwan government has a law about the protection of personal data (The Personal Data Protection Act) [1]. However, the exceptions have been used and expanded liberally during the COVID-19 pandemic, with the government citing an emergency situation [2].

There is no requirement to inform about data breaches. During the COVID-19 pandemic, there was an accusation using an existing law (Communication Security and Surveillance Act (CSSA)) in order to bypass the need for permission in order to use the CDC's SMS contact tracing system for criminal investigation, but the accusation was later denied.[2]

The Government of Taiwan ('the Government') has submitted its application to the EU for an adequacy decision pursuant to the General Data Protection Regulation and continues to dialog with EU in this regard. Meanwhile, the Government is evaluating whether the PDPA needs to be further amended in order to further align the PDPA with the GDPR.[3]

However, without an independent data protection agency, there is a gap between the PDPA and the GDPR, and the potential for breaches of privacy is higher.[4] The government indicates that this is upcoming for 2022. 

[1] National Development Council. Amended 2015. Personal Data Protection Act. https://law.moj.gov.tw/ENG/LawClass/LawAll.aspx?pcode=I0050021
[2] Chuan-Feng Wu. June 2021. COVID-19 and Data Privacy Challenges in Taiwan. https://lexatlas-c19.org/covid-19-and-data-privacy-challenges-in-taiwan/
[3] Onetrust Data Guidance. 2021. Taiwan Data Protection Overview. https://www.dataguidance.com/notes/taiwan-data-protection-overview. 
[4] Taiwan Human Rights Promotion Organization. 2018. Where to find a specialized agency. https://www.tahr.org.tw/news/2268.

evidence.title: Covid-19 and Data Privacy Challenges in Taiwan

responses.response_text: A framework exists and has the force of law.

The framework requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches.
Frameworks explicitly cover the protection of location-related data.
The framework addresses algorithmic decision making.
Exceptions to the usual data protection framework have been made as part of the country's COVID-19 response.

indicators.justification:
Several laws govern what a national language is: The Development of National Languages Act [1], the Indigenous Languages Development Act [2] https://law.moj.gov.tw/ENG/LawClass/LawAll.aspx?pcode=D0130037) and the Hakka Basic Act [3]. 

In addition, the "Blueprint for Developing Taiwan into a Bilingual Nation by 2030" [4] is relevant.

indicators.justification:
Taiwan does not have a comprehensive open-data law. Instead, there is a mixture of policy (which does not have the force of law) and executive orders (which do have the force of law). [1] The government provides a list of 12 relevant documents on the About Us page of the Open Data platform [2]. Also relevant at the local level is the Freedom of Information Law [3].

[1] Open Culture Foundation. Taiwan 2014-2016 Open Government Report. https://opengovreport.ocf.tw/assets/pdf/report-en.pdf
[2] Data.gov.tw. About Us. https://data.gov.tw/en/about
[3] Ministry of Justice. 2005. Freedom of Information Law. https://law.moj.gov.tw/ENG/LawClass/LawAll.aspx?pcode=I0020026

responses.response_text: A framework exists but lacks full force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework establishes a common definition of open data.
The framework promotes open licensing without any restrictions beyond attribution and share-alike.
The framework requires to publish data in machine readable formats.
The rules/guidance requires the use of specific data standards.
The framework promotes training and capacity building among government officials.

responses.response_text: The relevant laws, policies and guidance assessed cover the majority of localities and government agencies.
responses.subquestion_text: How widely do these laws, regulations, policies or guidance apply?

indicators.justification:
Taiwan has no special rules or regulations that require the disclosure of budgets, although Article 29 of the Budget Act states that the Executive Yuan should "try" to make a report on Statistics on National Wealth, Green National Income Account and report on tax expenditures and transferring expenditures, which shall be disclosed on the government website [1].

However, the Budget Act can and is read with the Freedom of Government Information Law [2] to assist in the release of information. In recent years, the pdf file format has been transformed into formatted data, which has been done in response to the voice of the people.

[1] Budget Act 2021. https://law.moj.gov.tw/ENG/LawClass/LawAll.aspx?pcode=T0020001
[2] Ministry of Justice. 2005. Freedom of Government Information Law. https://law.moj.gov.tw/ENG/LawClass/LawAll.aspx?pcode=I0020026

indicators.justification:
Taiwan has clear declaration requirements for party politics, politicians, civil servants, and parliamentarians [1], but some still need to be strengthened. For example, the assistants of parliamentarians have not yet declared, and they are sometimes reduced to white gloves (meaning they use someone else's name to avoid supervision). This aspect is under discussion.[2]

indicators.justification:
The Lobbying Act is poorly designed and it does not deter people from engaging in corruption, with the record of zero fines being issued for breaches of the act since its establishment in 2007.

In Asian political culture, lobbying is mostly based on connections. Although lobbying is practiced, it is essentially a mere formality, and most of it will be conducted through other channels.

https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2020/09/23/2003743927

indicators.justification:
There is no overall framework for public consultation in rulemaking [1]. However, the Ministry of Finance does have a relevant set of guidelines [2]. Civil society has been quite active in pushing public participation, especially via the vTaiwan open consultation platform, which has the backing of Digital Minister Audrey Tang.[3] Join.gov.tw has also been developed by the National Developmemt Council to facilitate public participation. Regulatory processes are now announced on here.[4] There is a policy regarding online participation on public policy [5] but it does not refer to publication of any data about the processes.

[1] Claudio Ndeleva Mutua. 2019. Digital Democracy and Public Participation in Taiwan: A Lesson for Kenya. https://nairobilawmonthly.com/index.php/2019/07/05/digital-democracy-and-public-participation-in-taiwan-a-lesson-for-kenya/
[2] Operational Guidelines Governing the Notice of the Laws and Regulations drafted by the Ministry of Finance https://law-out.mof.gov.tw/LawContent.aspx?id=GL010173
[3] VTaiwan Platform. https://info.vtaiwan.tw/
[4] Join Platform. https://join.gov.tw/
[5] National Development Council. 2018. Directions for Implementing Online Participation in Public Policy. https://theme.ndc.gov.tw/lawout/EngLawContent.aspx?lan=E&id=62

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the publication of notice of intent in advance of public consultation processes.
The framework requires the publication of proposed regulations.
The framework requires the timely publication of a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes.
The framework requires reasoned responses to be published alongside comments.
The framework requires the publication of final regulations and justification.
The framework requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

responses.response_text: They cover one or more localities, but there are many other localities without such rules/guidance, or with rules or guidance of a lesser quality.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification: There is no legal framework governing the publication of information about FOI requests.

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding the number of requests submitted and processed.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding how long it took the relevant government agency or agencies to fill requests.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding material withheld and the reasons for withholding it.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding appeals to RTI determinations and their results.
The framework requires that information is linked to the relevant agency, department, or other governmental entity.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

indicators.justification: Not available.

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of such products or services in the country.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used in products/services?
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, government.
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, civil society
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, the private sector.
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, media.
There is evidence that at least one of the examples cited is making use of beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data

indicators.justification:
There are isolated incidents of use of land data but it is unclear the level of impact it has had so far. In the 2020 Hackathon a non-profit/CSO group used agricultural land geodata, along with other relevant open datasets from the government, to investigate illegal underground factories in Taiwan. 

Private companies also use open housing or land sales data to obtain housing prices, and use AI and other tools to develop a tool to help people who are buying houses or land.
indicators.indicator_name: Use (L): Influencing policy for gender and inclusion
indicators.indicator_name_medium: Gender and inclusion uses of data
indicators.indicator_name_short: Gender and inclusion uses of data

responses.response_text: There are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use?
There is evidence of civil society organizations using data in this way.
There is evidence of media using data in this way.
There is evidence of academics using data in this way.
There is evidence of the private sector using data in this way.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
Is there evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts on land policy?

indicators.justification:
Although the property, investment, land and housing of politicians are clearly defined, it is difficult to see corruption and other content from these materials, and there are occasional fraud cases, and the unit still needs to be inspected for inspection.[1]

[1] Jui-Hua Fan and Lucas (Lung-Kuan) Wang. 2019. Lobbying in Taiwan. http://www.aalep.eu/lobbying-taiwan

responses.response_text: There are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data for accountability purposes, though the source may not be open data.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used for accountability purposes?
Civil society organizations regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The media regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
Scholars or academic institutions regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The private sector regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification:
After joining the WTO, the Taiwanese government had to abide by the regulations of international procurement. It has significantly improved information disclosure in the past ten years. Private organizations will count the companies that have obtained more bids, so that the transparency of governance will be improved.[1]

[1] Yu, Tzu-Yun. 2018. A Study of Using Open Government Data for Government Procurement.
https://ah.nccu.edu.tw/item?item_id=136859&locale=en-US

responses.response_text: There is evidence that these uses are widespread, regular and embedded.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.
